Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History: Securing and Digitizing Data for Parasite Biodiversity Specimens in the Manter Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to make data associated with the H.W. Manter Laboratory (HWML) more readily available to the scientific community, as well as to facilitate long-term security and conservation of its specimens. These important collections contribute to the ability of scientists in the USA to predict emerging diseases, understand global environmental changes, and enable responses to these threats to the national security by scientists and policymakers. Donated by top-ranked research scientists, four collections of parasites are being integrated into the HWML. These contain important knowledge of the biodiversity of parasites and their hosts, and this work will allow the HWML to database, conserve, and repair a large number of specimens that have remained un-catalogued (and unknown) for many years. The McDonald collection incorporates helminths from migratory waterfowl of the central North American flyway; the Wilson collection contains both identified and unidentified ectoparasites collected worldwide; the Hargis marine platyhelminth collection holds specimens from the Antarctic, Gulf of Mexico, and southern oceans; and the Telford hemoparasite slide collection holds parasites collected from reptiles worldwide.

The primary objectives of this project include converting an existing but outdated database, PARASITE, into a modern relational database system (Arctos, a multiuser online database for natural history and biodiversity collections), which will then be the HWML's main database, enabling scientists world-wide to query the collections for both digital images and data. Arctos will permit users to simultaneously target both vertebrate host collections and the parasites of these hosts - a capability currently unavailable in PARASITE. Such relational queries are essential to enable a complete picture of host/parasite biodiversity to research scientists working in many different fields. In coordination with the digitization effort, all specimens in four key parasite collections which are the last remaining backlogged sections of uncataloged specimens in the HWML will be repaired, or marked for future repair, and transfered into permanent-secure physical storage. All data resulting from this project will be posted online (http://hwml.unl.edu/) and shared with iDigBio (https://www.idigbio.org/), ensuring accessibility to researchers and educators.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Manter Laboratory of Parasitology was created in 1971 when the Division of Parasitology was officially added to the University of Nebraska State Museum. Since it was established, the lab has trained over 100 graduate students and scholars. The lab regularly loans and receives specimens that are used in research involving parasites world-wide. In the last 5 years (excluding 2020, year of COVID19) research scholars spent a combined time of about 2,000 hours/year in the Manter Laboratory, using the specimen collections, microscopy facilities, and the integrated research library. Both the library and the specimen collections are world-class and are found nowhere else on the planet. In addition to training and support of research in parasite systematics and parasitology in general, each year visitors to the lab contribute directly to the University by assisting with teaching and research that is ongoing in the Manter lab. In addition, visitors contribute directly to the economy of the state in the hospitality, transportation, and food vending sectors of business.

The primary goal of the NSF funded project was to make the HWML’s specimens and associated computerized databases more readily available to the scientific community. We also wished to conserve specimens in the collections for the long-term, stop any degradation of important specimens, and we worked to improve the long-term security of the collections in the lab. Objective 1 was to convert the local database, PARASITE, into a relational database system in Arctos. This has occurred and Arctos is now serving our data to scientists world-wide via the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) and this enables scientists to simultaneously query both vertebrate host collections and the parasites of these hosts using remote computer interfaces. Such relational queries are essential to enable a complete picture of host/parasite biodiversity to enable research by scientists working in many different fields. Objective 2 was to catalog into Arctos (digitize data records), repair, or mark for future repair, and transfer into permanent-secure physical storage all specimens in four key parasite collections which were the last remaining backlogged (non-cataloged and non-curated) sections of specimens in the HWML. These are as follows: The Malcolm McDonald collection incorporates helminths from migratory waterfowl (mostly ducks and geese) of the central North American flyway; the Nixon Wilson collection contains identified and unidentified ectoparasites collected from mammals worldwide with special focus on North America and the United States; the Hargis marine platyhelminth collection includes specimens from oceans around Antarctica, through the Gulf of Mexico, and Chesapeake Bay; and the Sam Telford hemoparasite slide collection which consists of blood parasites on slides collected from reptiles worldwide.

Work completed has provided researchers with a functional, high-speed, interlinked, web-accessible database that includes access to information on diagnostic (how to identify by how it looks) and DNA characteristics (molecular DNA information that is used for genetics and identification to species, where available) along with host data. Host data includes the species of host from which the parasite was collected and locality or geographic distributions (from where on the earth it was found). The result of this work has been to increase the efficiency with which research in biology, ecology, and health sciences can be conducted, enabling new ways of studying host-parasite biodiversity, marine ecology, and many other fields of biology while at the same time providing a predictive framework for examining the origin and spread of parasites of wildlife including diseases that can transfer from animals to man. Our work makes information in the collection readily available for use in prediction of new distributions of parasites due to changes in climate and other factors. This information now includes the development and use of species distribution maps that may show increases or decreases in parasite ranges in geographic areas due to human impacts or due to invasive species.

In addition to continuing to involve undergraduate students in research, the project team created collaborative teaching modules with the University of Nebraska State Museum to conduct public outreach through a "Parasite Universe Summer Camp," a one-week program that introduces underprivileged middle school students to parasite biodiversity, and a workshop for professional development for middle and high school science teachers that provided research experiences and inquiry-based activities that assisted teacher-implementation of Next Generation Science Standards in schools.

More broadly, the Arctos conversion and incorporation of these important collections enabled creation and dissemination of new information, providing new capabilities to researchers with who can use new tools available, like mapping and ecological predictions using computers. Finally, to the undergraduate students who participated in this work, this grant from the NSF stressed the importance of parasites in natural systems, while enabling the identification of the species of parasites that occur in wild and domestic animals that have the potential to transfer to humans, much as did the  virus, such as SARS-CoV2.

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2020
Modified by: Scott L Gardner
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Manter Laboratory of Parasitology was created in 1971 when the Division of Parasitology was officially added to the University of Nebraska State Museum. Since it was established, the lab has trained over 100 graduate students and scholars. The lab regularly loans and receives specimens that are used in research involving parasites world-wide. In the last 5 years (excluding 2020, year of COVID19) research scholars spent a combined time of about 2,000 hours/year in the Manter Laboratory, using the specimen collections, microscopy facilities, and the integrated research library. Both the library and the specimen collections are world-class and are found nowhere else on the planet. In addition to training and support of research in parasite systematics and parasitology in general, each year visitors to the lab contribute directly to the University by assisting with teaching and research that is ongoing in the Manter lab. In addition, visitors contribute directly to the economy of the state in the hospitality, transportation, and food vending sectors of business. The primary goal of the NSF funded project was to make the HWML’s specimens and associated computerized databases more readily available to the scientific community. We also wished to conserve specimens in the collections for the long-term, stop any degradation of important specimens, and we worked to improve the long-term security of the collections in the lab. Objective 1 was to convert the local database, PARASITE, into a relational database system in Arctos. This has occurred and Arctos is now serving our data to scientists world-wide via the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) and this enables scientists to simultaneously query both vertebrate host collections and the parasites of these hosts using remote computer interfaces. Such relational queries are essential to enable a complete picture of host/parasite biodiversity to enable research by scientists working in many different fields. Objective 2 was to catalog into Arctos (digitize data records), repair, or mark for future repair, and transfer into permanent-secure physical storage all specimens in four key parasite collections which were the last remaining backlogged (non-cataloged and non-curated) sections of specimens in the HWML. These are as follows: The Malcolm McDonald collection incorporates helminths from migratory waterfowl (mostly ducks and geese) of the central North American flyway; the Nixon Wilson collection contains identified and unidentified ectoparasites collected from mammals worldwide with special focus on North America and the United States; the Hargis marine platyhelminth collection includes specimens from oceans around Antarctica, through the Gulf of Mexico, and Chesapeake Bay; and the Sam Telford hemoparasite slide collection which consists of blood parasites on slides collected from reptiles worldwide. Work completed has provided researchers with a functional, high-speed, interlinked, web-accessible database that includes access to information on diagnostic (how to identify by how it looks) and DNA characteristics (molecular DNA information that is used for genetics and identification to species, where available) along with host data. Host data includes the species of host from which the parasite was collected and locality or geographic distributions (from where on the earth it was found). The result of this work has been to increase the efficiency with which research in biology, ecology, and health sciences can be conducted, enabling new ways of studying host-parasite biodiversity, marine ecology, and many other fields of biology while at the same time providing a predictive framework for examining the origin and spread of parasites of wildlife including diseases that can transfer from animals to man. Our work makes information in the collection readily available for use in prediction of new distributions of parasites due to changes in climate and other factors. This information now includes the development and use of species distribution maps that may show increases or decreases in parasite ranges in geographic areas due to human impacts or due to invasive species. In addition to continuing to involve undergraduate students in research, the project team created collaborative teaching modules with the University of Nebraska State Museum to conduct public outreach through a "Parasite Universe Summer Camp," a one-week program that introduces underprivileged middle school students to parasite biodiversity, and a workshop for professional development for middle and high school science teachers that provided research experiences and inquiry-based activities that assisted teacher-implementation of Next Generation Science Standards in schools. More broadly, the Arctos conversion and incorporation of these important collections enabled creation and dissemination of new information, providing new capabilities to researchers with who can use new tools available, like mapping and ecological predictions using computers. Finally, to the undergraduate students who participated in this work, this grant from the NSF stressed the importance of parasites in natural systems, while enabling the identification of the species of parasites that occur in wild and domestic animals that have the potential to transfer to humans, much as did the virus, such as SARS-CoV2.
